semantic__foreword.semantic__p:
A comparison of the ozone reference standards of the Czech Hydrometeorological Institute (CHMI) and of the Bureau International des Poids et Mesures (BIPM) has been performed. Both institutes maintain Standard Reference Photometers (SRPs), developed by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), as their reference standards. The instruments were compared over a nominal ozone mole fraction range of
0
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
0 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" to
860
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
860 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" and the results showed good agreement.

semantic__clause.semantic__p:
A comparison of the ozone reference standards of the Czech Hydrometeorological Institute (CHMI) and of the Bureau International des Poids et Mesures (BIPM) has been performed. Both institutes maintain Standard Reference Photometers (SRPs) developed by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) as their reference standards. This comparison was performed following the protocol established for the key comparison BIPM.QM-K1, adapted to the measurement range normally covered by the CHMI as part of their calibration service, which is
10
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
10 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" to
870
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
870 "unitsml(nmol/mol)". The measurement protocol is described briefly in . A description of the standards is given in of this report, together with their uncertainty budgets. The data treatment is explained in , and the results of the comparison are given in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The measurements were performed on 20 September 2017 at the BIPM.

This comparison was performed following the protocol established for the key comparison BIPM.QM-K1, with a modified measurement range: the instruments were compared over a nominal ozone mole fraction range of
0
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
0 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" to
860
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
860 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" (instead of a nominal range of
0
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
0 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" to
500
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
500 "unitsml(nmol/mol)").
The comparison protocol is summarized in this section. The complete version can be downloaded from the BIPM website ().

This comparison was performed following protocol A, corresponding to a direct comparison between the CHMI national standard SRP17 and the common reference standard BIPM-SRP27 maintained at the BIPM. A comparison between two (or more) ozone photometers consists of producing ozone-air mixtures at different amount-of-substance fractions over the required range, and measuring these with the photometers.

The same source of purified air is used for all the ozone photometers being compared. This air is used to provide reference air as well as the ozone–air mixture to each ozone photometer. Ambient air is used as the source for reference air. The air is compressed with an oil-free compressor. It is dried and scrubbed using a commercial purification system so that the mole fraction of ozone and nitrogen oxides remaining in the air is below detectable limits. The relative humidity of the reference air is monitored and the mole fraction of water in air is typically less than
3
µmol
⋅
mol
− 1
3 "unitsml(umol/mol)". The mole fraction of volatile organic hydrocarbons in the reference air was measured (November 2002), with no mole fraction of any detected component exceeding
1
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
1 "unitsml(nmol/mol)".

A common dual external manifold in Pyrex is used to supply the necessary flows of reference air and ozone–air mixtures to the ozone photometers. The two columns of this manifold are vented to atmospheric pressure.

All the instruments were switched on and allowed to stabilize for at least 8 hours before the comparison commenced. The pressure and temperature measurement systems of the instruments were checked at this time. If any adjustments were required, these were noted. For this comparison, no adjustments were necessary.

One comparison run normally includes ten different amount-of-substance fractions distributed to cover the range, together with the measurement of reference air at the beginning and end of each run. The nominal amount-of-substance fractions were measured in a sequence imposed by the BIPM.QM-K1 protocol, plus three additional values to extend the range (0, 220, 80, 420, 120, 320, 30, 370, 170, 500, 270, 0, 570, 840, 700 and 0)
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
"unitsml(nmol/mol)". Each of these points is an average of ten single measurements.

For each nominal value of the ozone mole fraction
x nom
x_("nom") supplied by the ozone generator, the standard deviation
s SRP27
s_("SRP27") on the set of ten consecutive measurements
x
SRP27 , i
x_("SRP27",i) recorded by BIPM-SRP27 was calculated. The measurement results were considered as valid if
s SRP27
s_("SRP27") was less than
1
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
1 "unitsml(nmol/mol)", which ensures that the photometers were measuring a stable ozone concentration. If not, another series of ten consecutive measurements was performed.

The comparison procedure was repeated continuously for BIPM.QM-K1 to evaluate its repeatability. The participant and the BIPM jointly decided when both instruments were stable enough to start recording a set of measurement results to be considered as the official comparison results. The measurements reported here were recorded in an additional run that was performed immediately afterwards.
A second ozone reference standard, BIPM-SRP28, was included in the comparison to verify its agreement with BIPM-SRP27 and thus follow its stability over the period of the on-going key comparison.

All instruments included in this comparison were Standard Reference Photometers (SRP) built by the NIST. More details on the instrument’s operating principle and capabilities can be found in . The following section describes the SRP measurement principle and uncertainty budget.

semantic__clause.semantic__title: Measurement equation of a NIST SRP
semantic__clause.semantic__p:
The measurement of ozone mole fraction by an SRP is based on the absorption of radiation at
253.7
nm
253.7 "unitsml(nm)" by ozonized air in the gas cells of the instrument. One unique characteristic of the instrument design is the use of two gas cells to overcome the instability of the light source. The measurement equation is derived from the Beer–Lambert and ideal gas laws. The number concentration (
C
ii(C)) of ozone is calculated from:

semantic__dd.semantic__p:
is the absorption cross-section of ozone at
253.7
nm
253.7 "unitsml(nm)" under standard conditions of temperature and pressure,
1.1476 ×
10
− 17
cm
2
/molecule
1.1476 xx 10^(-17) "unitsml(cm^2)""/molecule" ;
is the optical path length of one of the cells;
is the measured temperature of the cells;
is the measured pressure of the cells;

is the product of transmittances of two cells, with the transmittance (
T
r
ii(T)_r) of one cell defined as
is the UV radiation intensity measured from the cell when containing ozonized air; and
is the UV radiation intensity measured from the cell when containing pure air (also called reference or zero air).

semantic__clause.semantic__p:
Using the ideal gas law, can be reformulated in order to express the measurement results as a mole fraction (
x
x) of ozone in air:

semantic__dd.semantic__p:
is the Avogadro constant,
6.022142 ×
10 23
mol
− 1
6.022142 xx 10^(23) "unitsml(mol^-1)", and

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The formulation implemented in the SRP software is:

semantic__dd.semantic__p:
is the linear absorption coefficient under standard conditions, expressed in
cm−1
"unitsml(cm^(-1))", linked to the absorption cross–section with the relation:

semantic__clause.semantic__p:
The linear absorption coefficient at standard conditions
α
x
ii(alpha)_"x" used within the SRP software algorithm is
308.32
cm
− 1
308.32 "unitsml(cm^-1)". This corresponds to a value for the absorption cross–section
σ
ii(sigma) of
1.1476 ×
10
− 17
cm
2
/molecule
1.1476 xx 10^(-17) "unitsml(cm^2)""/molecule", rather than the more often quoted
1.147 ×
10
− 17
cm
2
/molecule
1.147 xx 10^(-17) "unitsml(cm^2)""/molecule". In the comparison of two SRP instruments, the absorption cross section can be considered to have a conventional value and its uncertainty can be set to zero. However, in the comparison of different methods or when considering the complete uncertainty budget of the method the uncertainty of the absorption cross–section should be taken into account. A consensus value of 2.12 % at a 95 % level of confidence for the uncertainty of the absorption cross–section has been proposed by the BIPM and the NIST in a recent publication .

Compared to the original design described in , SRP27 and SRP28 have been modified to deal with two biases revealed by a study conducted by the BIPM and the NIST . In 2009, an “SRP upgrade kit” was installed in the instruments, as described in .

Compared to the original design, the CHMI SRP17 has been modified to deal with the two biases revealed in . In August 2007, an “SRP upgrade kit” was installed by NIST, as already described in the previous comparison report .

semantic__clause.semantic__title: Analysis of the measurement results by generalized least-squares regression
semantic__clause.semantic__p: The relationship between the national and reference standards was first evaluated with a generalized least-squares regression fit, using the OzonE software. This software, which is documented in a publication , is an extension of the previously used software B_Least recommended by ISO standard 6143:2001 . It includes the possibility to take into account correlations between measurements performed with the same instrument at different ozone mole fractions. It also facilitates the use of a transfer standard, by the handling of unavoidable correlations, which arise since this instrument needs to be calibrated by the reference standard.
In a direct comparison, a linear relationship between the ozone amount-of-substance fractions measured by SRPn and SRP27 is obtained:

The associated uncertainties on the slope
u
(
a 1
)
u(a_1) and the intercept
u
(
a 0
)
u(a_0) are given by OzonE, as well as the covariance between them and the usual statistical parameters to validate the fitting function.

SRP17, maintained by the CHMI, was compared with the SRPs maintained by the BIPM following the general procedure outlined above. A cycle of twelve comparison runs between SRP27, SRP28 and SRP17 were performed. Ozone was generated using the Environics 6100 generator with airflow of
10
L
⋅
min
− 1
10 "unitsml(L/min)". The nominal ozone mole fraction range covered during this exercise was
0 ⁢nmol⁢mol−1
0 "unitsml(nmol*mol^(-1))" to
500 ⁢nmol⁢mol−1
500 "unitsml(nmol*mol^(-1))" for the eleven first runs, then
0 ⁢nmol⁢mol−1
0 "unitsml(nmol*mol^(-1))" to
840 ⁢nmol⁢mol−1
840 "unitsml(nmol*mol^(-1))" for the last run. The result of the last comparison run is presented in detail in the . The repeatability of the results over the twelve runs is shown in , and the stability of the BIPM standards in .

The measurement results of the last of the twelve recorded runs are shown in . For each nominal ozone mole fraction, the standard deviation is reported on the ten successive measurements that were recorded. The values reported here show that both instruments were in a stable regime.

An interesting way to look at these results is to display the difference between the ozone amount-of-substance fractions measured by SRP17 and SRP27 (
x 17
–
x 27
x_(17) – x_(27)) versus the ozone mole fraction measured by SRP27. , shows that measurement results from both instruments differ little from each other over the entire concentration range of the comparison. Considering a coverage factor of
k = 2
k = 2 (95 % confidence interval), the difference between both standards is much lower than their combined measurement uncertainties.

The least-squares regression results confirm that a linear fit is appropriate, with a sum of the the squared deviations (SSD) of 0.30 and a goodness of fit (GoF) equal to 0.17.

To assess the agreement of the standards using , the difference between the calculated slope value and unity, and the intercept value and zero, together with their measurement uncertainties, need to be considered. In this comparison, the value of the intercept is consistent with an intercept of zero, considering the uncertainty in the value of this parameter; i.e

The results of the twelve comparison runs performed successively between SRP17 and SRP27 are reported in . With a standard deviation of
0.04
nmol

0.04 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" on the intercept and a relative standard deviation of 0.03 % on the slope, these data show a good repeatability.

semantic__clause.semantic__title: History of comparisons between BIPM SRP27, SRP28 and CHMI SRP17
semantic__clause.semantic__p:
Results of the previous comparison performed with CHMI, on the same measurement range and since the first one in December 2002, are shown in together with the results of this comparison. The slopes
a 1

x
SRP n
=

x SRP27

Results of previous comparisons have been corrected to take into account the changes in the reference BIPM-SRP27 described in , which explains the larger uncertainties associated with the corresponding slopes.
shows that all standards included in these comparisons remained in close agreement.

semantic__figure.semantic__name:
Results of previous comparisons between SRP27, SRP28 and CHMI-SRP17 realised at the BIPM. Uncertainties are calculated at
k = 2
k = 2, with the uncertainty budget in use at the time of each comparison.

semantic__clause.semantic__p:
For the sixth time in fifteen years, a direct comparison between the CHMI national standard SRP17 and the BIPM reference standard SRP27 has been conducted at the BIPM. The measurement range of the SRP17 at the CHMI is
10
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
10 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" to
870
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
870 "unitsml(nmol/mol)". This entire range was examined during the comparison, and the relative difference between the CHMI SRP17 and BIPM SRP27 measurement results was found to be much smaller than their combined measurement uncertainties.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__formattedref: Viallon J., Moussay P., Norris J.E., Guenther F.R. and Wielgosz R.I., 2006, A study of systematic biases and measurement uncertainties in ozone mole fraction measurements with the NIST Standard Reference Photometer Metrologia 43 441-450

Viallon J., Moussay P., Idrees F. and Wielgosz R.I., 2010, Upgrade of the BIPM Standard Reference Photometers for Ozone and the effect on the on-going key comparison BIPM.QM-K1, Rapport BIPM-2010/07, 16pp

Viallon J., Moussay P., Wielgosz R.I., Novák J. and Vokoun M., 2008, Final report of the on-going key comparison BIPM.QM-K1: Ozone at ambient level, comparison with CHMI, 2007 Metrologia 45, Tech. Supl. 08005
Bremser W., Viallon J. and Wielgosz R.I., 2007, Influence of correlation on the assessment of measurement result compatibility over a dynamic range Metrologia 44 495-504
ISO 6143.2 : 2001 Gas analysis — Determination of the composition of calibration gas mixtures — Comparison methods (International Organization for Standardization)

foreword.title: Foreword
foreword.p:
A comparison of the ozone reference standards of the Czech Hydrometeorological Institute (CHMI) and of the Bureau International des Poids et Mesures (BIPM) has been performed. Both institutes maintain Standard Reference Photometers (SRPs), developed by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), as their reference standards. The instruments were compared over a nominal ozone mole fraction range of
0
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
0 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" to
860
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
860 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" and the results showed good agreement.

clause.title: 1.Introduction
clause.p:
A comparison of the ozone reference standards of the Czech Hydrometeorological Institute (CHMI) and of the Bureau International des Poids et Mesures (BIPM) has been performed. Both institutes maintain Standard Reference Photometers (SRPs) developed by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) as their reference standards. This comparison was performed following the protocol established for the key comparison BIPM.QM-K1, adapted to the measurement range normally covered by the CHMI as part of their calibration service, which is
10
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
10 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" to
870
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
870 "unitsml(nmol/mol)". The measurement protocol is described briefly in Chapter 4. A description of the standards is given in Chapter 5 of this report, together with their uncertainty budgets. The data treatment is explained in Chapter 6, and the results of the comparison are given in Chapter 7.

clause.title: 3.Measurement schedule
clause.p: The measurements were performed on 20 September 2017 at the BIPM.

The comparison protocol is summarized in this section. The complete version can be downloaded from the BIPM website ().

This comparison was performed following protocol A, corresponding to a direct comparison between the CHMI national standard SRP17 and the common reference standard BIPM-SRP27 maintained at the BIPM. A comparison between two (or more) ozone photometers consists of producing ozone-air mixtures at different amount-of-substance fractions over the required range, and measuring these with the photometers.

clause.title: 4.1.Ozone generation
clause.p:
The same source of purified air is used for all the ozone photometers being compared. This air is used to provide reference air as well as the ozone–air mixture to each ozone photometer. Ambient air is used as the source for reference air. The air is compressed with an oil-free compressor. It is dried and scrubbed using a commercial purification system so that the mole fraction of ozone and nitrogen oxides remaining in the air is below detectable limits. The relative humidity of the reference air is monitored and the mole fraction of water in air is typically less than
3
µmol
⋅
mol
− 1
3 "unitsml(umol/mol)". The mole fraction of volatile organic hydrocarbons in the reference air was measured (November 2002), with no mole fraction of any detected component exceeding
1
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
1 "unitsml(nmol/mol)".

A common dual external manifold in Pyrex is used to supply the necessary flows of reference air and ozone–air mixtures to the ozone photometers. The two columns of this manifold are vented to atmospheric pressure.

clause.title: 4.2.Comparison procedure
clause.p: All the instruments were switched on and allowed to stabilize for at least 8 hours before the comparison commenced. The pressure and temperature measurement systems of the instruments were checked at this time. If any adjustments were required, these were noted. For this comparison, no adjustments were necessary.

One comparison run normally includes ten different amount-of-substance fractions distributed to cover the range, together with the measurement of reference air at the beginning and end of each run. The nominal amount-of-substance fractions were measured in a sequence imposed by the BIPM.QM-K1 protocol, plus three additional values to extend the range (0, 220, 80, 420, 120, 320, 30, 370, 170, 500, 270, 0, 570, 840, 700 and 0)
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
"unitsml(nmol/mol)". Each of these points is an average of ten single measurements.

For each nominal value of the ozone mole fraction
x nom
x_("nom") supplied by the ozone generator, the standard deviation
s SRP27
s_("SRP27") on the set of ten consecutive measurements
x
SRP27 , i
x_("SRP27",i) recorded by BIPM-SRP27 was calculated. The measurement results were considered as valid if
s SRP27
s_("SRP27") was less than
1
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
1 "unitsml(nmol/mol)", which ensures that the photometers were measuring a stable ozone concentration. If not, another series of ten consecutive measurements was performed.

clause.title: 4.3.Comparison repeatability
clause.p: The comparison procedure was repeated continuously for BIPM.QM-K1 to evaluate its repeatability. The participant and the BIPM jointly decided when both instruments were stable enough to start recording a set of measurement results to be considered as the official comparison results. The measurements reported here were recorded in an additional run that was performed immediately afterwards.

clause.title: 4.4.SRP27 stability check
clause.p: A second ozone reference standard, BIPM-SRP28, was included in the comparison to verify its agreement with BIPM-SRP27 and thus follow its stability over the period of the on-going key comparison.

clause.title: 5.Measurement standards
clause.p: All instruments included in this comparison were Standard Reference Photometers (SRP) built by the NIST. More details on the instrument’s operating principle and capabilities can be found in [1]. The following section describes the SRP measurement principle and uncertainty budget.

clause.title: 5.1.Measurement equation of a NIST SRP
clause.p:
The measurement of ozone mole fraction by an SRP is based on the absorption of radiation at
253.7
nm
253.7 "unitsml(nm)" by ozonized air in the gas cells of the instrument. One unique characteristic of the instrument design is the use of two gas cells to overcome the instability of the light source. The measurement equation is derived from the Beer–Lambert and ideal gas laws. The number concentration (
C
ii(C)) of ozone is calculated from:

253.7

1.1476 ×

− 17

1.1476 xx 10^(-17) "unitsml(cm^2)""/molecule" [2];
is the optical path length of one of the cells;
is the measured temperature of the cells;
is the measured pressure of the cells;

is the product of transmittances of two cells, with the transmittance (
T
r

is the UV radiation intensity measured from the cell when containing ozonized air; and
is the UV radiation intensity measured from the cell when containing pure air (also called reference or zero air).

clause.p:
Using the ideal gas law, Equation (1) can be reformulated in order to express the measurement results as a mole fraction (
x

clause.title: 5.2.Absorption cross–section for ozone
clause.p:
The linear absorption coefficient at standard conditions
α
x
ii(alpha)_"x" used within the SRP software algorithm is
308.32
cm
− 1
308.32 "unitsml(cm^-1)". This corresponds to a value for the absorption cross–section
σ
ii(sigma) of
1.1476 ×
10
− 17
cm
2
/molecule
1.1476 xx 10^(-17) "unitsml(cm^2)""/molecule", rather than the more often quoted
1.147 ×
10
− 17
cm
2
/molecule
1.147 xx 10^(-17) "unitsml(cm^2)""/molecule". In the comparison of two SRP instruments, the absorption cross section can be considered to have a conventional value and its uncertainty can be set to zero. However, in the comparison of different methods or when considering the complete uncertainty budget of the method the uncertainty of the absorption cross–section should be taken into account. A consensus value of 2.12 % at a 95 % level of confidence for the uncertainty of the absorption cross–section has been proposed by the BIPM and the NIST in a recent publication [3].

clause.title: 5.3.Condition of the BIPM SRPs
clause.p: Compared to the original design described in [1], SRP27 and SRP28 have been modified to deal with two biases revealed by a study conducted by the BIPM and the NIST [3]. In 2009, an “SRP upgrade kit” was installed in the instruments, as described in [4].

clause.p: Correlations in-between the results of two measurements, performed at two different ozone amount-of-substance fractions with the BIPM–SRP27, were taken into account in the OzonE software. clause.title: 5.6.Condition of the CHMI SRP17
clause.p: Compared to the original design, the CHMI SRP17 has been modified to deal with the two biases revealed in [3]. In August 2007, an “SRP upgrade kit” was installed by NIST, as already described in the previous comparison report [5].

clause.title: 6.Analysis of the measurement results by generalized least-squares regression
clause.p: The relationship between the national and reference standards was first evaluated with a generalized least-squares regression fit, using the OzonE software. This software, which is documented in a publication [6], is an extension of the previously used software B_Least recommended by ISO standard 6143:2001 [7]. It includes the possibility to take into account correlations between measurements performed with the same instrument at different ozone mole fractions. It also facilitates the use of a transfer standard, by the handling of unavoidable correlations, which arise since this instrument needs to be calibrated by the reference standard.
In a direct comparison, a linear relationship between the ozone amount-of-substance fractions measured by SRPn and SRP27 is obtained:

The associated uncertainties on the slope
u
(
a 1
)
u(a_1) and the intercept
u
(
a 0
)
u(a_0) are given by OzonE, as well as the covariance between them and the usual statistical parameters to validate the fitting function.

clause.title: 7.Results of the comparison
clause.p:
SRP17, maintained by the CHMI, was compared with the SRPs maintained by the BIPM following the general procedure outlined above. A cycle of twelve comparison runs between SRP27, SRP28 and SRP17 were performed. Ozone was generated using the Environics 6100 generator with airflow of
10
L
⋅
min
− 1
10 "unitsml(L/min)". The nominal ozone mole fraction range covered during this exercise was
0 ⁢nmol⁢mol−1
0 "unitsml(nmol*mol^(-1))" to
500 ⁢nmol⁢mol−1
500 "unitsml(nmol*mol^(-1))" for the eleven first runs, then
0 ⁢nmol⁢mol−1
0 "unitsml(nmol*mol^(-1))" to
840 ⁢nmol⁢mol−1
840 "unitsml(nmol*mol^(-1))" for the last run. The result of the last comparison run is presented in detail in the Section 7.1. The repeatability of the results over the twelve runs is shown in Section 7.2, and the stability of the BIPM standards in Section 7.3.

clause.title: 7.1.Measurement results
clause.p: The measurement results of the last of the twelve recorded runs are shown in Table 3. For each nominal ozone mole fraction, the standard deviation is reported on the ten successive measurements that were recorded. The values reported here show that both instruments were in a stable regime.

An interesting way to look at these results is to display the difference between the ozone amount-of-substance fractions measured by SRP17 and SRP27 (
x 17
–
x 27
x_(17) – x_(27)) versus the ozone mole fraction measured by SRP27. Figure 1, shows that measurement results from both instruments differ little from each other over the entire concentration range of the comparison. Considering a coverage factor of
k = 2
k = 2 (95 % confidence interval), the difference between both standards is much lower than their combined measurement uncertainties.

table.name: Table 3.measurement results of the comparison between the CHMI standard SRP17 and the BIPM reference standard SRP27

figure.name: Figure 1 — difference between the ozone amount-of-substance fractions measured by SRP17 and SRP27 versus the ozone mole fraction measured by SRP27.

The least-squares regression results confirm that a linear fit is appropriate, with a sum of the the squared deviations (SSD) of 0.30 and a goodness of fit (GoF) equal to 0.17.

To assess the agreement of the standards using Equation (10), the difference between the calculated slope value and unity, and the intercept value and zero, together with their measurement uncertainties, need to be considered. In this comparison, the value of the intercept is consistent with an intercept of zero, considering the uncertainty in the value of this parameter; i.e

clause.title: 7.2.Repeatability
clause.p:
The results of the twelve comparison runs performed successively between SRP17 and SRP27 are reported in Table 4. With a standard deviation of
0.04
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
0.04 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" on the intercept and a relative standard deviation of 0.03 % on the slope, these data show a good repeatability.

table.name: Table 4.results of the ten comparison runs repeated successively

clause.title: 7.3.History of comparisons between BIPM SRP27, SRP28 and CHMI SRP17
clause.p:
Results of the previous comparison performed with CHMI, on the same measurement range and since the first one in December 2002, are shown in Figure 2 together with the results of this comparison. The slopes
a 1
a_1 of the linear relation
x
SRP n
=
a 0
+
a 1
x SRP27
x_("SRP"n) = a_0 + a_1 x_("SRP27") are represented together with their associated uncertainties calculated at the time of each comparison. Results of previous comparisons have been corrected to take into account the changes in the reference BIPM-SRP27 described in [4], which explains the larger uncertainties associated with the corresponding slopes.
Figure 2 shows that all standards included in these comparisons remained in close agreement.

figure.name:
Figure 2 — Results of previous comparisons between SRP27, SRP28 and CHMI-SRP17 realised at the BIPM. Uncertainties are calculated at
k = 2
k = 2, with the uncertainty budget in use at the time of each comparison.

clause.title: 8.Conclusion
clause.p:
For the sixth time in fifteen years, a direct comparison between the CHMI national standard SRP17 and the BIPM reference standard SRP27 has been conducted at the BIPM. The measurement range of the SRP17 at the CHMI is
10
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
10 "unitsml(nmol/mol)" to
870
nmol
⋅
mol
− 1
870 "unitsml(nmol/mol)". This entire range was examined during the comparison, and the relative difference between the CHMI SRP17 and BIPM SRP27 measurement results was found to be much smaller than their combined measurement uncertainties.
